title: Blog
text:
Welcome to my blog, where I share thoughts on research methods, teaching experiences, and insights from the field of accounting and finance. Here you’ll find a mix of academic reflections, practical tips for researchers, and commentary on emerging trends in financial reporting and transparency.

This blog represents my personal views and reflections. Posts are added periodically as research projects develop or as interesting questions arise in my teaching and research.








Tips for doctoral students and early career researchers on developing research questions, navigating the publication process, and building productive collaborations.
Read more →







Reflections on integrating data analytics tools into traditional accounting curricula and preparing students for an increasingly automated financial landscape.
Read more →

Associate Professor at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University Rotterdam
Primary research focus: Economic consequences of reporting transparency
Currently, I am interested in how disclosure practices affect individual and/or market behavior and corporate outcomes.

My research has been published in leading journals including Journal of Financial Economics, The Accounting Review, and The Review of Financial Studies, investigating how information environments impact corporate misconduct, industry coordination, and mergers & acquisitions, with a particular focus on the interplay between information asymmetry and regulatory frameworks.








We show that companies named after their owners tend to be more opaque in their financial disclosures, particularly when revealing such information might expose sensitive owner details and attract social stigma. We also show that when disclosure is forced, these owners are more likely to change their firms’ names, and new firms are less frequently named after their founding owners.
Read Paper →







We investigate the impact of mandatory financial disclosure on mergers and acquisitions. We find that required disclosure boosts M&A activity by reducing information frictions, as evidenced by an increase in both the number and volume of private firms becoming targets.
Read Paper →

title: Presentations
text:
March 2025 at RSM
This presentation was part of the Advanced Research Methods course. The is the first of two presentations that the Accounting and Finance department sahre with the students. The goal is to provide an overview of research in the field of accounting and finance, and to introduce the students to some of research methods that they could use in their own BSc projects. The goal is to provide a gentle introduction to the research process and to inspire students to think about their own research projects.
Advanced Research Methods




September 2024 at RSM
The presentation below was meant to bring our incoming academic director up to speed with the current developments in our new Data and Coding online course. By now, it ran for the first time and I hopefully have the time to update the slides to reflect the experiences and feedback from the first run.
